text.content:
Welcome to the Verbal Development module.

The purpose of this module is to help professionals:

  • Understand the importance of toddler years in the development of language and communication skills
  • Promote healthy language and literacy development

Parents and caregivers play a critical role in supporting a young child’s language skills. Babies and toddlers learn language through social interactions because language is primarily a social behavior.

Many parents instinctively promote their child’s linguistic development by talking, singing and reading. Through these daily interactions, children learn to talk by:
  • Acquiring vocabulary
  • Using phrases and sentences
  • Engaging in conversation

Educator Training Goals:

Present research-based findings that describe how young children learn language.

Identify and describe the various aspects of language acquisition.

Provide ways for professionals to communicate the importance of parents' roles in their child’s language development.

graphic.notes: Cognitive Learning Master 10 mo Makayla pic, in the Verbal Development folder within the Communication and Lang folder
Photo 3 (2), dad on couch with baby, mom leaning in and smiling, in the Verbal Development folder within the Comm and Lang folder
Brooklynn with Mom and Dad, parents reading with baby, in Verbal Dev. folder,within the Comm and Lang folder

audio.transcript: Welcome to the Verbal Development module. The purpose of this module is to help professionals understand the importance of the toddler years in the development of language and communication skills, and provide information for parents that promote healthy language and literacy development in the day-to-day activities of children ages 18 months to 3 years.

In this module, you'll learn that parents and caregivers play a critical role in supporting a young child’s language and communication skills. Research shows that babies and toddlers learn language through social interactions because language is primarily a social behavior.

Many parents instinctively help to promote their child’s linguistic development by talking, singing and reading. Through these daily interactions, children learn to talk by acquiring vocabulary; using phrases and sentences; and engaging in conversation. This module will look at how these skills evolve between a toddlers first and third birthday.

After completing this module, you will be able to: 1. Present research-based findings that describe how young children learn language during the second and third years of life. 2. Identify and describe the various aspects of language acquisition, including important milestones. And 3. Provide simple, yet effective ways for professionals to communicate the importance of parents’ roles in their child’s language development. To begin, click a Topic in the bottom menu.
